Get Started¶

pyETT: Python API client for Eleven VR Table Tennis data

[1]:

import pyETT
import pandas as pd

Player and user search¶

In order to get player’s information we first need to uniquely identify a player. We can use the user_search() method of an object of the class ETT to search players by username, as follows:

[2]:

ett = pyETT.ETT()
ett.user_search_dataframe('Highlander')

[2]:
id name elo rank wins losses last_online
0 248681 Highlandersge 1488.0 361225 0 1 2021-03-30T17:29:28.963Z
1 246892 mwwhighlander 1500.0 222424 0 0 2021-01-02T23:00:36.762Z
2 218318 .::Highlander::. 1500.0 179327 0 0 2021-01-07T00:52:31.209Z
3 166876 The Highlander 1530.0 16962 4 1 2020-12-01T20:22:39.752Z
4 348353 highlanderNJ 1980.5 2288 457 364 2021-06-16T21:48:07.262Z
5 174851 Highlander 1500.0 202898 0 0 2021-01-29T22:24:38.479Z
6 273705 vikinghighlander 1430.0 361738 1 13 2021-03-05T22:47:34.303Z
7 384291 highlander10 1500.0 71453 0 0 2021-04-16T22:18:26.874Z
8 349180 brHighlandeR 1480.0 377943 1 3 2021-04-02T14:52:05.130Z
9 388282 Fred THighlander 1500.0 330717 0 0 2021-03-13T22:19:41.219Z
10 281262 Highlander34 1500.0 241598 0 0 2021-01-19T01:31:25.454Z
11 342761 HighLandeR 1509.0 55912 4 0 2021-06-05T18:10:00.747Z
12 456783 Highlander75 1500.0 380346 0 0 2021-04-22T02:04:49.941Z
13 397168 OGHighlanderr 1500.0 149347 2 0 2021-03-24T05:57:07.701Z

Here, the function returns all players that contains the input username string ‘Highlander’. If we wanted to search for a perfect match, we can pass the argument perfect_match=True:

[3]:

ett.user_search_dataframe('highlanderNJ', perfect_match=True)

[3]:
id name elo rank wins losses last_online
0 348353 highlanderNJ 1980.5 2288 457 364 2021-06-16T21:48:07.262Z

In this search, we were able to find the player with username ‘highlanderNJ’ which turns our to be me. We can now instantiate a Player object to obtain his information:

[4]:

print(p:=pyETT.Player(348353))

highlanderNJ

[5]:

print(f"username:{p.name}\n elo:{p.elo}\n rank:{p.rank}\n wins:{p.wins}\n losses:{p.losses}\n")

username:highlanderNJ
 elo:1980.5
 rank:2288
 wins:457
 losses:364

We can see I have an elo number of 1980.5, which puts me ranked in number 2288 in the world with 457 ranked wins and 364 losses. That’s not entirely bad as the total number of active players is of the magnitude of about 200 thousand users!

Matches and rounds¶

Now that we have instantiated a Player object, we can obtain his matches using the method get_matches() or get_matches_dataframe() to obtain his matches in a nice pandas dataframe.

[6]:

m = p.get_matches_dataframe().head()
m

[6]:
created_at id ranked number_of_rounds state winning_team losing_team home_score away_score home_player away_player rounds
0 2021-06-14T21:33:02.826Z 9334404 True 3 1 1 0 0 2 pete_ed5 highlanderNJ [<pyETT.Match.Round object at 0x7f283549c880>,...
1 2021-06-14T21:29:40.751Z 9334315 True 3 1 1 0 0 2 pete_ed5 highlanderNJ [<pyETT.Match.Round object at 0x7f283549c940>,...
2 2021-06-14T21:26:32.527Z 9334230 True 3 1 0 1 2 0 pete_ed5 highlanderNJ [<pyETT.Match.Round object at 0x7f283549c730>,...
3 2021-06-14T16:15:47.297Z 9326236 True 3 1 0 1 2 1 highlanderNJ FatCatPat69 [<pyETT.Match.Round object at 0x7f283549c550>,...
4 2021-06-14T15:50:48.549Z 9325651 True 3 1 1 0 0 2 ThePongFather highlanderNJ [<pyETT.Match.Round object at 0x7f283549cc40>,...

We can see that my latest match was against the player with username ‘pete_ed5’ and I won the match with a 2 x 0 score against him. In order to obtain, the rounds information, we can use the method get_rounds_dataframe from the class Match, as follows:

[7]:

pyETT.Match.get_rounds_dataframe(m.rounds[0])

[7]:
id round_number state away_score home_score winner created_at
0 20931563 0 0 11 8 1 2021-06-14T21:35:29.753Z
1 20931405 0 0 11 8 1 2021-06-14T21:33:02.826Z

Friends list, leaderboard and elo history¶

From the library, we can also obtain a player’s friends list with the method get_friends() of a player, which also has a corresponding method that returns a list of friends in a pandas dataframe:

[73]:

p.get_friends_dataframe().head()

[73]:
id name elo rank wins losses last_online elo_history
0 249045 Buttersmier 1886.0 3656 65 59 2021-06-15T21:30:17.883Z elo 2021-02-06T15...
1 431729 JoeSixPaK 1700.5 8863 335 563 2021-06-16T02:40:18.813Z elo 2021-04-08T17...
2 495551 77696c6c 1500.0 165378 0 0 2021-06-14T16:21:31.027Z None
3 456082 pete_ed5 1811.0 5170 98 91 2021-06-16T22:21:07.097Z elo 2021-04-21T20...
4 468947 dargonfar 1499.0 436880 56 90 2021-06-16T15:24:29.938Z elo 2021-06-02T20...

I’m interested in comparing my elo with my friends’. For that purpose, we can get a player’s elo history with the method get_elo_history():

[74]:

p_elo = p.get_elo_history()
p_elo.head()

[74]:
elo
2021-02-20T21:13:12.497Z 1500.0
2021-02-24T03:06:30.809Z 1513.0
2021-02-24T03:13:06.512Z 1502.0
2021-02-24T03:16:20.774Z 1489.0
2021-02-24T03:19:46.168Z 1482.0 
[56]:

from functools import reduce

n_friends = 5

friends_elo = [f.get_elo_history().rename(columns={"elo":f.name}) for f in
               p.get_friends()[-n_friends:] if f.get_elo_history() is not None]

friends_elo.append(p.get_elo_history().rename(columns={"elo":p.name}))

group_elo_df = reduce(lambda df1,df2: pd.merge(df1,df2,how='outer', left_index=True, right_index=True),
                      friends_elo).ffill(axis = 0)

[54]:

group_elo_df

[54]:
Buttersmier JoeSixPaK pete_ed5 dargonfar highlanderNJ
2021-02-06T15:57:55.235Z 1500.0 NaN NaN NaN NaN

2021-02-06T16:07:43.695Z 1482.0 NaN NaN NaN NaN
2021-02-06T16:09:59.066Z 1476.0 NaN NaN NaN NaN

2021-06-16T21:56:39.187Z 1871.0 1705.5 1828.0 1507.0 1973.5

2181 rows × 5 columns

[80]:

group_elo_df.plot(figsize=(10,8))

[80]:

<matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x7f281ccb77c0>

Now let’s take a look at the leaderboard.

[83]:

ett.get_leaderboard_dataframe()

[83]:
id name elo rank wins losses last_online elo_history
0 385684 yedat 3238.2 0 948 258 2021-06-14T20:11:03.190Z elo 2021-03-12T18...
1 347650 PROTT_VR 3095.0 1 662 119 2021-06-11T12:50:47.018Z elo 2021-02-17T19...

[81]:

lb_elo = [f.get_elo_history().rename(columns={"elo":f.name}) for f in
               ett.get_leaderboard() if f.get_elo_history() is not None]

lb_elo.append(p.get_elo_history().rename(columns={"elo":p.name}))

lb_elo_df = reduce(lambda df1,df2: pd.merge(df1,df2,how='outer', left_index=True, right_index=True),
                      lb_elo).ffill(axis = 0)

[82]:

lb_elo_df.plot(figsize=(10,8))

[82]:

<matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x7f281c8ffd30>
